cleaned_text: Obesity In Some Arctic Groups Have Been Linked To Instant Noodles](//science.slashdot.org/story/17/02/27/2124235/first-signs-of-obesity-in-some-arctic-groups-have-been-linked-to-instant-noodles) [ (sciencealert.com) ](http://www.sciencealert.com/the-first-signs-of-obesity-in-certain-arctic-groups-have-been-linked-to-instant-noodles) [242](//science.slashdot.org/story/17/02/27/2124235/first-signs-of-obesity-in-some-arctic-groups-have-been-linked-to-instant-noodles#comments) [schwit1](/~schwit1)quotes a report from ScienceAlert: Researchers have [noted the first signs of obesity in the native ethnic groups of the Yamalo-Nenets region](http://www.sciencealert.com/the-first-signs-of-obesity-in-certain-arctic-groups-have-been-linked-to-instant-noodles)-- an autonomous district that sits on the coast of the Arctic Ocean in Northwest Siberia. [According to local experts](http://siberiantimes.com/science/opinion/features/f0289-first-ever-cases-of-obesity-in-arctic-peoples-as-noodles-replace-traditional-diet/), obesity has not previously existed in these indigenous populations, but the first cases are now being reported, and a marked change in diet -- including instant noodles and pasta -- appears to be responsible. The Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug has a population of just over 522,000 people, whose ancestors have survived the permafrost for millennia. The nomadic Nenets and Khanty peoples have been herding reindeer up and down the Yamal tundra -- a 700-km-long peninsula that stretches deep into the Arctic Ocean -- for 1,000 years, with diets heavily based on venison and fish. But that appears to be changing fast, as researchers note the increasing uptake of chemically processed foods, such as instant noodles and pasta, and the addition of sugar, pastry, and bread to their diets. According to Titovsky, these changes -- which have only been occurring over the past few years -- have seen the intake of venison and river fish cut by half.
